Comment: It's just amusing. We see stories all the time about how the Democrats are losing younger voters *and* that the manosphere is fueling a far-right ideology growth amongst younger men.   Then they drag out Ezra Klein when there's literally a guy like Hasan Piker who is a leftist that's extremely popular with younger voters, has a manosphere-like following, and has connections to several Democratic politicians within the Progressive caucus (several of whom have sat down with him, from AOC to Bernie to Greg Casar to Ro Khanna) and literally went and recorded live from the DNC.   Having a guy like Piker appear with you would drastically improve your turnout amongst younger voters.   But then, voters might pressure the DNC into enacting leftist policies that Piker supports, which would be a big no-no in their eyes.

Author: LimberGravy

Comment: The fundamental problem is that Democrats don't know how to talk to people, and (perhaps more importantly) don't know how to sympathize with people. Democrats do a poor job acknowledging people's pain.   Democrats will often do a whole big song and dance that basically goes "I don't understand what the big deal is, here's a series of facts explaining why your feelings are wrong."   In the case of the economy for example, your average Democrat leader will say things like, "What are you talking about? The economy is great! Look at the stock market! Look at the unemployment rate! Look at the GDP!" It does nothing to acknowledge their pain and suffering, and essentially makes them look crazy.  All of those metrics are worthless if you are working two jobs and are still struggling to make ends meet.   This is something the Republicans do very well, but only for the wrong reason. They will say, "We feel you. The economy is terrible, and it's because of the Democrat's weak border policy and influx of illegal immigrants. If we win, we will deport all of them which will improve the cost of living."   Republicans validate emotions, blame some marginalized group, and claim to be able to fix it.   Bernie Sanders (and AOC to some degree) is able to do this well. If you listen to him talk about the economy, he essentially starts by saying "the economy is rigged against you, your pain is valid" and then blames the appropriate parties (corporate greed, big money in politics) and proposes policy solutions to fix it.
Author: walkallover1991
